metadata.titleEn: The historical similation and projection dataset of 73-station Central Asia extreme precipition indices (1979-2100)
metadata.description: A statistical downscaling model based on quantile delta mapping (QDM) was used to simulate historical (1979-2014)  simulation and project future scenarios of 8 extreme precipitation indices from 73 stations in five Central Asian countries (annual total precipitation PRCPTOT, total extreme precipitation R95PTOT, annual precipitation days R1MM, annual precipitation days greater than 10mm R10MM, annual maximum 1-day precipitation RX1DAY, maximum consecutive  precipitation days CWD, maximum consecutive dry days CDD, average precipitation intensity SDII). These include 10 the results of statistical downscaling from 10 global climate models under two socio-economic pathways (SSP245 and SSP585)
metadata.instructions: PrintmodelSSPQDMn.txt, where print represents extreme precipitation index, model represents global climate model, SSP represents socio-economic path, QDM represents statistical downscaling method, and n represents station number.

background: Central Asia (CA) is a typical arid and semi-arid region in the hinterland of the Eurasian continent. It is characterized by scarce water resources and fragile ecosystems that are sensitive and vulnerable to climate change (Liu et al., 2020). Under the context of global warming, CA has experienced profound climate warming since the 20th century, much faster than the global land average (Giorgi, 2006; Huang et al., 2017; Jiang et al., 2020). In response to global change, extreme temperature (e.g., heatwave) and precipitation (e.g., drought and heavy precipitation) events have occurred more frequently and intensely in CA in the last 50 years than ever before (Reyer et al., 2017; Yu et al., 2020). Most studies on projecting precipitation changes and extremes in CA have been based on GCM simulations (Wu et al., 2013; Reyer et al., 2017; Peng et al., 2020; Guo et al., 2021). However, due to their limited resolutions, global climate models (GCMs) simulations have significant biases relative to the observed climate variables such as temperature and precipitation over CA (Reyer et al., 2017; Peng et al., 2020). Regional climate models (RCMs) produce finer resolution information about regional climate changes than GCMs do (Mannig et al., 2013; Qiu et al., 2017, 2022; Zhu et al., 2020). Statistical downscaling (SD) models are a practicable tool to bridge the scale gap between climate model simulations and station observations.
research objective: In this study, we proposed a statistical downscaling (SD) model based on quantile delta mapping to assess and project eight precipitation indices at 73 meteorological stations across CA driven by ERA5 reanalysis data and simulations of 10 global climate models (GCMs) for present and future (2081-2100) periods under two shared socio-economic pathways (SSP245 and SSP585). In this study, we applied an SD model based on QDM to evaluate and project daily precipitation and extremes across CA, so as to gain a deeper understanding of the response of the station-level extreme precipitation to global warming, and to further obtain more accurate prediction of extreme precipitation at meteorological stations in CA at the end of the 21st century than GCMs, which is very imperative for local climate change impact assessment.
challenges: However, global and regional climate models often fail to reproduce the observed daily precipitation distribution and hence extremes, especially in areas with complex terrain. Due to the high computational cost, RCM is difficult to be applied in the study of multi-model ensemble projection and uncertainty. Moreover, simulated precipitation outputs from GCMs and even RCMs usually exhibit considerable biases partly because the model data represent area averages over grid boxes, while observations are derived from rain gauges at specific point locations. In fact, at the grid scale, the intensities of extreme precipitation events simulated using GCMs and RCMs are usually much weaker than those observed at weather stations (Elizabeth et al., 2010).
methods: The QDM algorithm was adopted in this study to downscale the future daily precipitation at a station by combining the QM algorithm with a quantile delta change approach (Cannon et al., 2015). The QM algorithm was applied to interpolate the missing precipitation data of the 73 stations in CA using the daily gridded precipitation data from APHRODITE as inputs. The cross-validation method was used to evaluate the performance of the SD model (Fan et al., 2013). The SD model was used to project the changes in the precipitation indices toward the end of the 21st century under scenarios SSP245 and SSP585, and then, the results were compared with the results of the raw GCM simulations to assess the added value of the SD model.
dataset: Daily precipitation observations in the five countries in CA were obtained from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) Global Historical Climatology Networks (GHCN). Due to a lack of daily precipitation data for most of the stations in CA since 2005, only data from 73 stations with less than 25% missing data in the entire period from 1979 to 2005 were adopted. The daily gridded precipitation dataset (APHRODITE) developed by Yatagai et al. (2009, 2012) was used to interpolate the missing precipitation data at the selected stations in CA. The daily gridded precipitation from the European Centre for Medium Weather Forecasts (ECMWF) fifth generation atmospheric (ERA5) reanalysis data with a spatially horizontal resolution of 2.5° × 2.5° for 1979-2005 was used to force the proposed SD model before the SD model was applied to the GCM simulations. The 10 CMIP6 GCMs were selected (Table 1). The historical simulations for 1979-2014 and future projections of the daily precipitation under scenarios SSP245 and SSP585 from 2015 to 2100 were applied to downscale the daily precipitation at 73 stations.
findings: The SD model effectively reduces the biases and RMSEs of the modeled precipitation indices compared to the observations. Also, it effectively adjusts the distributional biases in the downscaled daily precipitation and indices at the stations across CA. Our SD multi-model ensemble projections project significant and robust increases in SDII and total extreme precipitation (R95PTOT) of 0.5 mm/d and 19.7 mm, respectively, over CA at the end of the 21st century (2081-2100) compared to the present values (1995-2014). More pronounced increases in indices R95PTOT, SDII, number of very wet days (R10MM), and RX1DAY are projected under the higher emission scenario (SSP585), particularly in the mountainous southeastern region. The SD model suggested that SDII and RX1DAY will likely rise more rapidly than those projected by previous model simulations over CA during the period 2081-2100.

Verification.Question: Can the quantile delta mapping (QDM) method effectively address the biases in daily precipitation data when applied to datasets in Central Asia?
Is the cross-validation method used to evaluate the performance of statistical downscaling models in precipitation studies?

Concept Completion.Question: Where do the daily precipitation observations for Central Asia originate from, and what challenges are associated with these datasets?
Who are the primary sources of the gridded precipitation data used to interpolate missing station data in Central Asia?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of how a statistical downscaling model can be used to improve precipitation data accuracy in regions with complex terrain?
Example.Answer: The QDM algorithm was employed to downscale future daily precipitation at stations by combining the QM algorithm with a quantile delta change approach. This method effectively reduces biases and RMSEs of the modeled precipitation indices compared to observations, particularly in areas with complex terrain.

Example.Question: What is an example of a dataset that could be used to fill gaps in historical precipitation data for Central Asia?
Example.Answer: The daily gridded precipitation dataset developed by APHRODITE was used to interpolate missing precipitation data at selected stations in Central Asia, ensuring a more complete dataset for historical analysis.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a challenge in using global climate models to project precipitation changes in Central Asia?
Example.Answer: Global climate models often exhibit considerable biases because their data represent area averages over grid boxes, while observations are derived from rain gauges at specific point locations. This results in the simulated intensities of extreme precipitation events being usually much weaker than those observed at weather stations.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the methods used to address biases in modeled precipitation indices compared to observed data in regional climate studies?
What challenges are associated with simulating precipitation events using global climate models in regions with complex terrain?
Feature Specification.Answer: failing to reproduce observed daily precipitation distributions, considerable biases, area averages over grid boxes, weaker intensities of extreme precipitation events

Quantification.Question: What is the spatial resolution of the ERA5 reanalysis data used to force the statistical downscaling model?

Definition.Question: What is the Quantile Delta Mapping (QDM) approach in statistical downscaling models used for climate data?
Definition.Answer: The Quantile Delta Mapping (QDM) approach is a statistical downscaling method that combines the quantile mapping (QM) algorithm with a quantile delta change approach to downscale future daily precipitation data at meteorological stations. It is used to address biases and improve the accuracy of modeled climate variables, such as precipitation, by adjusting the distributional biases in the downscaled data.

Definition.Question: What challenges are typically faced when using global and regional climate models for projecting precipitation changes?
Definition.Answer: Challenges include the limited resolutions of global climate models (GCMs), which can lead to significant biases relative to observed climate variables, such as temperature and precipitation. Additionally, both global and regional climate models often fail to reproduce the observed daily precipitation distribution and extremes, especially in areas with complex terrain. Simulated precipitation outputs usually exhibit considerable biases because model data represent area averages over grid boxes, while observations are derived from specific point locations.

Definition.Question: What datasets are typically used to obtain daily precipitation observations in Central Asia for climate studies?
Definition.Answer: Datasets used include daily precipitation observations from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) Global Historical Climatology Networks (GHCN). For missing data interpolation, the daily gridded precipitation dataset known as APHRODITE is used. Additionally, the ERA5 reanalysis data from the European Centre for Medium Weather Forecasts (ECMWF) with a spatially horizontal resolution of 2.5° × 2.5° is used to force statistical downscaling models before applying them to global climate model simulations.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges might arise when using gridded precipitation datasets to interpolate missing data at specific meteorological stations, and how can these challenges affect the interpretation of extreme precipitation indices?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges include potential biases due to the spatial mismatch between gridded data and point observations. These biases can affect the reliability of interpolated data and thus the accuracy of extreme precipitation indices. Gridded data represent area averages, while observations are from specific locations, which can lead to underestimation of extremes. Addressing these challenges is crucial for accurate climate change impact assessments.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways do the biases and RMSEs of modeled precipitation indices impact the interpretation of future precipitation scenarios under different socio-economic pathways?
Interpretation.Answer: Biases and RMSEs in modeled precipitation indices can skew the interpretation of future precipitation scenarios, potentially leading to inaccurate assessments of changes in extreme precipitation patterns. By effectively reducing these biases and RMSEs, more reliable projections under different socio-economic pathways can be achieved, enhancing the understanding of how extreme precipitation may evolve and impact Central Asia's climate.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the biases and RMSEs in modeled precipitation indices when compared to observed data?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Global and regional climate models often fail to reproduce the observed daily precipitation distribution and hence extremes, especially in areas with complex terrain. Simulated precipitation outputs from GCMs and even RCMs usually exhibit considerable biases partly because the model data represent area averages over grid boxes, while observations are derived from rain gauges at specific point locations.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of using statistical downscaling models for projecting precipitation indices in regions with complex terrain, compared to relying solely on global climate models?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of statistical downscaling models, such as those based on quantile delta mapping, helps reduce biases and root mean square errors in modeled precipitation indices compared to observations. It effectively adjusts distributional biases in downscaled daily precipitation and indices, offering more accurate predictions, especially in areas with complex terrain where global climate models often fail to reproduce observed precipitation distributions.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications of using a multi-model ensemble approach in statistical downscaling for future projections of extreme precipitation under different socio-economic pathways?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using a multi-model ensemble approach in statistical downscaling provides significant and robust projections of increases in extreme precipitation indices, such as SDII and R95PTOT, under different socio-economic pathways. It allows for a comprehensive assessment of potential future changes, offering insights into more pronounced increases in precipitation indices under higher emission scenarios, particularly in sensitive regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the intentions behind comparing the results of the statistical downscaling model with raw GCM simulations?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intention behind comparing the results of the statistical downscaling model with raw GCM simulations is to assess the added value of the statistical downscaling model in reducing biases and root mean square errors of the modeled precipitation indices. This comparison helps to evaluate the effectiveness of the downscaling model in adjusting distributional biases in the downscaled daily precipitation and indices at the stations across Central Asia, thereby enhancing the accuracy of future projections.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the steps involved in utilizing a statistical downscaling model to assess and project precipitation indices at meteorological stations?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The steps involve using a QDM algorithm to downscale future daily precipitation at a station by combining the QM algorithm with a quantile delta change approach. The QM algorithm interpolates missing data, and cross-validation evaluates the model's performance. The SD model is then used to project precipitation indices changes under different scenarios and compare these with raw GCM simulation results.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can missing precipitation data be interpolated using daily gridded datasets in regional climate studies?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Missing precipitation data can be interpolated by using a daily gridded precipitation dataset like APHRODITE, which provides the necessary inputs to fill gaps in station observations. This approach is applied to interpolate missing data at selected meteorological stations.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are taken to validate a statistical downscaling model in the context of climate predictions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The validation of a statistical downscaling model includes using a cross-validation method to evaluate its performance. This involves comparing the modeled precipitation indices against observed data to ensure the model effectively reduces biases and RMSEs, and adjusts distributional biases in the downscaled data across stations.

Enablement.Question: What data collection methods enable the accurate projection of extreme precipitation indices in arid regions like Central Asia?
Enablement.Answer: The use of statistical downscaling models based on quantile delta mapping, which involves historical simulations and future projections from global climate models (GCMs) under scenarios such as SSP245 and SSP585, enables accurate projection of extreme precipitation indices. These methods help bridge the scale gap between model simulations and station observations.

Enablement.Question: How does combining multiple datasets enhance the ability to predict future precipitation patterns in Central Asia?
Enablement.Answer: Combining datasets like the NOAA Global Historical Climatology Networks (GHCN) for daily precipitation observations, APHRODITE for interpolating missing data, and ERA5 reanalysis data to force the statistical downscaling model, alongside simulations from 10 CMIP6 GCMs, enhances the ability to predict future precipitation patterns by providing a comprehensive data foundation for more accurate projections.

Enablement.Question: What challenges in data collection might affect the accuracy of climate projections in regions with complex terrain, and how can these be mitigated?
Enablement.Answer: Challenges include the failure of global and regional climate models to reproduce observed daily precipitation distributions and extremes, especially in complex terrains, due to biases and computational limitations. These can be mitigated by using statistical downscaling models that adjust distributional biases, reduce RMSEs, and provide finer resolution information than raw GCM simulations.

Expectation.Question: Why might data collection methods for extreme precipitation events in Central Asia face challenges in accurately representing daily precipitation distributions?
Expectation.Answer: Global and regional climate models often fail to reproduce the observed daily precipitation distribution and hence extremes, especially in areas with complex terrain. This is partly because model data represent area averages over grid boxes, while observations are derived from rain gauges at specific point locations.

Expectation.Question: Why might relying solely on global climate models for future precipitation projections in Central Asia be insufficient?
Expectation.Answer: Global climate models have significant biases relative to observed climate variables such as temperature and precipitation over Central Asia due to their limited resolutions. They often fail to capture the detailed spatial and temporal characteristics of precipitation, which are crucial for accurate predictions of extreme events, leading to the necessity for additional methods like statistical downscaling.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of the QDM-based statistical downscaling model in addressing the challenges of bias in daily precipitation distribution in complex terrains?
Judgmental.Answer: The QDM-based statistical downscaling model is considered effective as it reduces biases and RMSEs in modeled precipitation indices compared to observations. It also adjusts distributional biases in the downscaled daily precipitation and indices at the stations across Central Asia, particularly in areas with complex terrain.

Judgmental.Question: What is your opinion on the potential limitations of using historical simulations and socio-economic pathways (SSP245 and SSP585) for future projections of extreme precipitation indices?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of historical simulations and socio-economic pathways like SSP245 and SSP585 might face limitations due to the inherent biases in GCM and RCM outputs. These models often struggle with reproducing observed daily precipitation distributions, especially in regions with complex topography, which can affect the accuracy of future projections.

Judgmental.Question: How do you perceive the role of datasets like NOAA GHCN and APHRODITE in refining precipitation data collection methods for improved station-level extreme precipitation predictions?
Judgmental.Answer: Datasets like NOAA GHCN and APHRODITE play a crucial role in refining precipitation data collection methods. They provide essential historical and gridded precipitation data, which are used to address missing data issues and improve the accuracy of station-level extreme precipitation predictions through statistical downscaling approaches.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges involved in using global climate models (GCMs) for projecting precipitation indices in regions with complex terrain.
Assertion.Answer: Global and regional climate models often fail to reproduce the observed daily precipitation distribution and extremes in areas with complex terrain. This is due to biases in model data representing area averages over grid boxes, while observations are derived from specific point locations, leading to weaker simulated intensities of extreme precipitation events.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of why certain datasets are chosen for interpolating missing precipitation data at meteorological stations.
Assertion.Answer: The daily gridded precipitation dataset (APHRODITE) was used to interpolate missing precipitation data at selected stations because it provided daily precipitation inputs for the QM algorithm, aiding in the accurate downscaling of historical and future precipitation data.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the impact of using different statistical downscaling techniques on the accuracy of extreme precipitation projections in arid regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: The QDM algorithm is used to downscale future daily precipitation, combining the QM algorithm with a quantile delta change approach. This approach reduces biases and RMSEs of modeled precipitation indices compared to observations and adjusts distributional biases in downscaled daily precipitation and indices across Central Asia.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential challenges in obtaining accurate precipitation data in regions with complex terrain and suggest methods to address these challenges.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges include the inability of global and regional climate models to reproduce observed daily precipitation distributions, especially in complex terrains. This is partly due to biases from model data representing area averages over grid boxes, while observations come from specific point locations. A practicable tool to handle these challenges is statistical downscaling models, which bridge the scale gap between climate model simulations and station observations.

Request/Directive.Question: Please investigate possible methods for enhancing the completeness and reliability of historical precipitation datasets in Central Asia.
Request/Directive.Answer: To enhance historical precipitation datasets, the QM algorithm can be applied to interpolate missing data using daily gridded precipitation data from sources like APHRODITE. Additionally, reanalysis data such as ERA5 can be used for forcing statistical downscaling models before applying them to GCM simulations, ensuring a more complete and reliable dataset.
